title: Tektite
summary: Tektites (from Ancient Greek  τηκτός (tēktós) 'molten') are gravel-sized bodies composed of black, green, brown, or gray natural glass formed from terrestrial debris ejected during meteorite impacts. The term was coined by Austrian geologist Franz Eduard Suess (1867–1941), son of Eduard Suess.[note 1][1] They generally range in size from millimeters to centimeters. Millimeter-scale tektites are known as microtektites.[2][3][4]
